content: Pay attention to your emotions and moods. Depression is a medical condition that prevents the brain from regulating its emotions. Everyone feels down occasionally, but people suffering from depression frequently experience certain emotions or a combination of them. If you experience these emotions, or if they prevent you from functioning in your everyday life, then it is important to seek help. Some emotions you might feel if you are depressed include: [1] Sadness . Are you often sad or low-spirited? Emptiness or numbness . Do you feel as though you have no emotions at all, or have trouble feeling anything? Hopelessness . Have you felt tempted to "give up", or had trouble imagining any improvement? Have you become more of a pessimist since you began suspecting depression? Guilt. Do you often feel guilty for little or no reason? Do these feelings stay with you and interfere with your ability to concentrate or enjoy yourself? Worthlessness . Do you have a low sense of self-worth? Irritability . Have you been snapping at people or getting into arguments without good reason? A short temper is another example of a mood change sometimes caused by depression, especially among men and teenagers. [2] Low energy . Do you often feel tired, unable to perform routine tasks or concentrate, and prone to avoiding active motion? Indecisiveness . Do you have difficulty making minor decisions? Does attempting to make decisions make you feel overwhelmed and hopeless? Watch for a desire to withdraw or isolate from friends and family. People who suffer from depression often stop spending time with friends, or lose interest in other things they used to enjoy. [3] This is because they have a desire to isolate themselves or withdraw from their usual activities. Consider your desire to withdraw or isolate from people and how your social life and daily activities have changed in the past few months or over the past year. Make a list of the activities you regularly participated in before you started feeling worse, and estimate how often you did each one. Over the next couple weeks, make a note whenever you do one of these activities and see if your rate has significantly decreased. Identify any suicidal thoughts. If you have thought about hurting yourself or even killing yourself, then it is important to seek immediate medical attention. Call emergency services right away, such as by dialing 911 in the US. Some other indications of suicidal tendencies include: [4] Fantasizing about hurting or killing yourself. Giving away belongings and/or putting your affairs in order. Saying a final goodbye to people. Feeling like you are trapped or that there is no hope. Saying or thinking things like, “I would be better off dead,” or “People would be happier without me around.” Making a quick transition from feeling hopeless and depressed to feeling happy and calm. Keep an eye out for appetite changes. Sudden weight gain or weight loss could be a sign of any number of medical issues, but even if depression is not the cause, you should still consult a doctor. If you have noticed that your appetite has increased or decreased significantly, then be sure to talk to your doctor about this as well. This may be a symptom of depression, or it could indicate another underlying problem. Note any risky behaviors. You may also consider any risky behaviors that you have adopted as a symptom. This is especially true for men with depression. If you have recently started engaging in drug and/or alcohol use, unsafe sex, reckless driving, or dangerous sports, then this may indicate depression. [5] Consider how often or how easily you cry. Frequent crying paired with other symptoms could indicate depression, especially if you aren't sure why you're crying. Consider how often you typically cry and what makes you cry. For example, if you find yourself crying for no reason or over something trivial, such as spilling a cup of water or missing your bus, then this is a good indication that you may be depressed. Be sure to share this symptom with your doctor. Tearfulness, or frequent crying, is a common symptoms of depression in teens. [6] Reflect on any mysterious aches and pains you have had. If you have frequent unexplained headaches or other pains, this is another good reason to consult a doctor. A medical condition may be to blame or the aches and pains may be due to depression. Physical pain is one of the more common and often overlooked signs of depression in men. If you are a man experiencing backaches, headaches, stomach problems, sexual dysfunction, or any other physical symptoms, be sure to tell your doctor. [7] Elderly people often complain about physical problems over mental or emotional ones, and so depression may hide for a long time. Be aware of any physical changes, deaths of friends, and losses of independence that could trigger depression. You may also notice things like having trouble sleeping, or sleeping too much. Consider potential causes and risk factors for depression. Depression is a complex disorder, and there's no simple test doctors can do to see whether or not you have it. However, there are many tools a therapist may use to check for depression, including having you fill out a questionnaire. Certain experiences can also cause or put you at risk for depression and sharing this information with a doctor or therapist may help them to make a diagnosis. Some potential causes and risk factors for depression may include: [8] Trauma and grief. Abuse or other violent experiences can cause depression, whether they occurred recently or otherwise. Grief after the death of a friend or other traumatic event can develop into full blown depression. Stressful events. Sudden changes, even positive ones such as getting married or starting a new job, could be responsible. More long term stress from caring for a sick person or going through a messy divorce are common triggers as well. Health conditions. Chronic pain, thyroid disease, and many other medical conditions can bring on depression, especially if you are fighting a long battle with an illness. Medication and substances. Read the side effects label on any medication you are taking. Avoid alcohol and other drugs to see if your symptoms improve; depressed people often abuse drugs, which makes the problem worse. Relationship problems . If you are struggling in one or more of your personal relationships, then this may also put you at risk of depression. Family history of depression . If a relative of yours has struggled with depression, then you are at a higher risk of developing it yourself. Loneliness, isolation, or a lack of social support . If you do not have a support system and spend a lot of time on your own, then this can also put you at risk of depression. Financial strain . If you have been struggling with debt or simply trying to keep up with your monthly expenses, then this can put you at risk of depression. [9] Consider whether you may have postpartum depression. If you recently gave birth, consider when the depression began. New mothers often experience mood swings, irritability, and other symptoms, which can range from minor to serious. If your depression began after delivery or at some point in the following few months, you may have postpartum depression. [10] Most new mothers experience "baby blues" symptoms for a few days, then recover on their own. This is probably due to hormonal changes and stress following birth. If you are having suicidal thoughts, or the depression is preventing you from caring for your baby, or if the symptoms last more than a week or two, consult a doctor immediately. Postpartum psychosis is a rare condition that can occur within two weeks of childbirth. If your depression symptoms are severe and accompanied by extreme mood swings, thoughts about harming your baby, or hallucinations, go to a hospital immediately. Consider whether your depression may be linked to fall or winter. If your symptoms appear as the days become shorter and darker, your depression may be Seasonal Affective Disorder, caused by too little sunlight. Exercise outdoors during daylight hours to see if you improve, or ask a doctor about artificial light treatment. [11] Not all temporary depression is seasonal affective disorder. Many people have depressive episodes that occur every few weeks, months, or years. If you are especially manic and energetic when you are not depressed, tell a doctor you may have bipolar disorder. Don't dismiss your depression if none of these causes apply. Many episodes of depression have a primarily biological or hormonal cause, or a cause that's difficult to identify. This does not make it any less serious or worth treating. Depression is a real medical condition, not something to feel ashamed of because you don't think you have a reason to be sad. Tell yourself you will become better quicker if you take fast action to seek help. Ask for help. Reaching out to people can help you to take the first step towards treatment. Your feelings of helplessness are part of your disorder, not reality, and that isolation feeds those feelings. Friends and family can help by listening to your problems, encouraging you to do something about it, and supporting you during the worst moments. [12] If you have trouble being active or leaving the house, let your friends know you're depressed and encourage them to keep inviting you to activities you enjoy even if you don't make it every time. Asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. Get a diagnosis. It is important to see a doctor if you suspect that you may have depression. This is because there are other conditions that may mimic depression, and your doctor will need to rule those out first. [13] Keep in mind that it is okay to get a second or even a third opinion, especially if you do not think that the doctor is hearing you or is not concentrating on the area that you think is most important. Your doctor can also give you a referral to see a therapist or a psychiatrist. Your doctor won't necessarily prescribe medication. If she thinks there's a specific cause of your depression, she may recommend a course of action or lifestyle changes instead. If your depression only lasts a few weeks and is gradually replaced by "high" periods of reckless energy, ask your doctor to consider bipolar disorder before taking any prescription medicine. Attend therapy or counseling. There are many types of therapists or counselors that can help you through recovery. You may even consider group therapy or a support group. Ask your primary care doctor for a referral. For example, you may find a depression support group to be helpful, or you may find a group like Alcoholics Anonymous or Narcotics Anonymous to be helpful if you have turned to substances as a way to cope. Take antidepressant medication. Once you are sure of your diagnosis and have begun taking steps to fight the depression, ask your doctor whether medication would be a good idea. Your doctor may prescribe antidepressants even if he thinks your main problem is an anxiety disorder, since they can be effective in treating those as well as depression. [14] Give the medication time to work. If you experience no changes after a few weeks, or if you can't stand the side effects, ask your doctor to prescribe a different medication. Keep in mind that medication is not meant for long-term use. It can help with your symptoms, but you will likely need to seek other forms of treatment as well, such as therapy, to see significant improvement. [15] Address the cause. Removing the underlying cause can be an effective way of treating depression. However, it is best to do this with the help of a therapist. If you are grieving, talk about your grief with friends, family, and mentors. Seek counseling to help you through the process. You can buy a workbook that addresses the grieving process as well. If you recently underwent a big change, try to figure out what parts of the change made you unhappy. If you moved to a city where you don't know anyone, then get out and explore the area, find something to do that interests you, join a special interest group, or look for a new hobby that you can share with others. You may also consider volunteering because helping other people may help you to feel better about yourself. If you thought you would like the change and aren't sure why you're responding with depression, talk to a counselor. If you suspect your depression is linked to your menstrual cycle or menopause, see a women’s health specialist, such as a gynecologist. Consult a doctor, counselor, or specialized support group if you have a chronic illness or substance abuse problem. Cultivate good relationships . Keep your friends close and connect with them regularly. It is especially important to turn to your friends and family when you need someone to talk to. Simply sharing how you are feeling with someone may help you to feel better. [16] If you want to make some new friends, then try joining a club of people who share an interest with you, or even a group you'd never thought of before. A regular meeting such as a weekly dance night or book club can make it easier to develop a habit of attending. If you're too shy to speak to strangers at one of these events, a smile and eye contact can be enough to start a conversation. Find a smaller group or one with people you're more comfortable around if you're experiencing severe anxiety about it. Make healthy lifestyle changes . Regular and sufficient sleep, regular exercise, and a healthy diet are all vital to lowering stress and encouraging a healthy emotional state. Consider meditation , massage, or other relaxation techniques. Use your support network. Ask about exercise advice from the professionals at your gym, and discuss relaxation methods including meditation. You can also research these topics online, or get a friend or housemate to help you build a schedule and stick to it. Exercise is especially helpful to include in your routine because it causes your brain to release endorphins, which make you feel good. Alcohol may temporarily relieve some of your depression, but it ultimately serves to worsen depression on a long-term basis. Drinking heavily may develop some symptoms of depression. Heavy drinking is known to lower the levels of serotonin in your brain, a chemical that helps boost your mood. [17]
title_html: How to Know if You Have Depression

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-You-Have-Depression">How to Know if You Have Depression</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Marsha Durkin, RN</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>

<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=marshadurkin%2Crn#marshadurkin%2Crn">Marsha Durkin, RN</a>. Marsha Durkin is a Registered Nurse in Wisconsin. She received her Associates Degree in Nursing from Olney Central College in 1987.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">18 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Depression can be short-term, lasting for just a couple of weeks, or long-term, lasting for years. It is normal to feel sad, lonely, or hopeless sometimes, such as after you experience a loss or during a time in your life when you are struggling. However, sometimes these normal feelings of sadness can turn into problematic depression. Untreated depression may continue for months or years, and may even threaten your life.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Considering_Your_Thoughts_and_Feelings_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Considering_Your_Thoughts_and_Feelings">Considering Your Thoughts and Feelings</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Antidepressant-Withdrawal-Step-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Ease-Antidepressant-Withdrawal-Step-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Antidepressant Withdrawal Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Ease-Antidepressant-Withdrawal-Step-5.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Ease-Antidepressant-Withdrawal-Step-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_a25eaea4fb" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a25eaea4fb')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Antidepressant Withdrawal Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Ease-Antidepressant-Withdrawal-Step-5.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Ease-Antidepressant-Withdrawal-Step-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Pay attention to your emotions and moods.</b> Depression is a medical condition that prevents the brain from regulating its emotions. Everyone feels down occasionally, but people suffering from depression frequently experience certain emotions or a combination of them. If you experience these emotions, or if they prevent you from functioning in your everyday life, then it is important to seek help. Some emotions you might feel if you are depressed include:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>
<b>Sadness</b>. Are you often sad or low-spirited?</li>
<li>
<b>Emptiness or numbness</b>. Do you feel as though you have no emotions at all, or have trouble feeling anything?</li>
<li>
<b>Hopelessness</b>. Have you felt tempted to "give up", or had trouble imagining any improvement? Have you become more of a pessimist since you began suspecting depression?</li>
<li>
<b>Guilt.</b> Do you often feel guilty for little or no reason? Do these feelings stay with you and interfere with your ability to concentrate or enjoy yourself?</li>
<li>
<b>Worthlessness</b>. Do you have a low sense of self-worth?</li>
<li>
<b>Irritability</b>. Have you been snapping at people or getting into arguments without good reason? A short temper is another example of a mood change sometimes caused by depression, especially among men and teenagers.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>
<b>Low energy</b>. Do you often feel tired, unable to perform routine tasks or concentrate, and prone to avoiding active motion?</li>
<li>
<b>Indecisiveness</b>. Do you have difficulty making minor decisions? Does attempting to make decisions make you feel overwhelmed and hopeless?</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Empathize-with-People-Who-Have-Suicidal-Tendencies-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Empathize-with-People-Who-Have-Suicidal-Tendencies-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Empathize with People Who Have Suicidal Tendencies Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Empathize-with-People-Who-Have-Suicidal-Tendencies-Step-7.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Empathize-with-People-Who-Have-Suicidal-Tendencies-Step-7.jpg" height="546" id="img_7a413f4125" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7a413f4125')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Empathize with People Who Have Suicidal Tendencies Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Empathize-with-People-Who-Have-Suicidal-Tendencies-Step-7.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Empathize-with-People-Who-Have-Suicidal-Tendencies-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Watch for a desire to withdraw or isolate from friends and family.</b> People who suffer from depression often stop spending time with friends, or lose interest in other things they used to enjoy.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup> This is because they have a desire to isolate themselves or withdraw from their usual activities. Consider your desire to withdraw or isolate from people and how your social life and daily activities have changed in the past few months or over the past year.

<ul>
<li>Make a list of the activities you regularly participated in before you started feeling worse, and estimate how often you did each one. Over the next couple weeks, make a note whenever you do one of these activities and see if your rate has significantly decreased.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Prevent Teen Suicide Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-11.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_383786fc70" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_383786fc70')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Prevent Teen Suicide Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-11.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Identify any suicidal thoughts.</b> If you have thought about hurting yourself or even killing yourself, then it is important to seek immediate medical attention. <a href="/Call-Emergency-Services" title="Call Emergency Services">Call emergency services</a> right away, such as by dialing 911 in the US. Some other indications of suicidal tendencies include:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Fantasizing about hurting or killing yourself.</li>
<li>Giving away belongings and/or putting your affairs in order.</li>
<li>Saying a final goodbye to people.</li>
<li>Feeling like you are trapped or that there is no hope.</li>
<li>Saying or thinking things like, “I would be better off dead,” or “People would be happier without me around.”</li>
<li>Making a quick transition from feeling hopeless and depressed to feeling happy and calm.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Identifying_Changes_in_Behavior_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Identifying_Changes_in_Behavior">Identifying Changes in Behavior</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Seek-Help-for-Bipolar-Disorder-(Manic-Depression)-Step-2-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Seek-Help-for-Bipolar-Disorder-(Manic-Depression)-Step-2-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Seek Help for Bipolar Disorder (Manic Depression) Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/62/Seek-Help-for-Bipolar-Disorder-%28Manic-Depression%29-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Seek-Help-for-Bipolar-Disorder-%28Manic-Depression%29-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_49f586b456" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_49f586b456')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Seek Help for Bipolar Disorder (Manic Depression) Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/62/Seek-Help-for-Bipolar-Disorder-%28Manic-Depression%29-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Seek-Help-for-Bipolar-Disorder-%28Manic-Depression%29-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Keep an eye out for appetite changes.</b> Sudden weight gain or weight loss could be a sign of any number of medical issues, but even if depression is not the cause, you should still consult a doctor. If you have noticed that your appetite has increased or decreased significantly, then be sure to talk to your doctor about this as well. This may be a symptom of depression, or it could indicate another underlying problem.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Tell-if-Someone-Is-Lying-About-Using-Drugs-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Tell-if-Someone-Is-Lying-About-Using-Drugs-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Tell if Someone Is Lying About Using Drugs Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Tell-if-Someone-Is-Lying-About-Using-Drugs-Step-12.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Tell-if-Someone-Is-Lying-About-Using-Drugs-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_e4c91d82f1" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e4c91d82f1')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Tell if Someone Is Lying About Using Drugs Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Tell-if-Someone-Is-Lying-About-Using-Drugs-Step-12.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Tell-if-Someone-Is-Lying-About-Using-Drugs-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Note any risky behaviors.</b> You may also consider any risky behaviors that you have adopted as a symptom. This is especially true for men with depression. If you have recently started engaging in drug and/or alcohol use, unsafe sex, reckless driving, or dangerous sports, then this may indicate depression.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Help-a-Suicidal-Family-Member-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Help-a-Suicidal-Family-Member-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Help a Suicidal Family Member Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Help-a-Suicidal-Family-Member-Step-11.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Help-a-Suicidal-Family-Member-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_ecf4dea518" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ecf4dea518')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Help a Suicidal Family Member Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Help-a-Suicidal-Family-Member-Step-11.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Help-a-Suicidal-Family-Member-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider how often or how easily you cry.</b> Frequent crying paired with other symptoms could indicate depression, especially if you aren't sure why you're crying. Consider how often you typically cry and what makes you cry.

<ul>
<li>For example, if you find yourself crying for no reason or over something trivial, such as spilling a cup of water or missing your bus, then this is a good indication that you may be depressed. Be sure to share this symptom with your doctor.</li>
<li>Tearfulness, or frequent crying, is a common symptoms of depression in teens.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-2-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-2-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Prevent Teen Suicide Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_fb7ca34436" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_fb7ca34436')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Prevent Teen Suicide Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Reflect on any mysterious aches and pains you have had.</b> If you have frequent unexplained headaches or other pains, this is another good reason to consult a doctor. A medical condition may be to blame or the aches and pains may be due to depression.

<ul>
<li>Physical pain is one of the more common and often overlooked signs of depression in men. If you are a man experiencing backaches, headaches, stomach problems, sexual dysfunction, or any other physical symptoms, be sure to tell your doctor.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Elderly people often complain about physical problems over mental or emotional ones, and so depression may hide for a long time. Be aware of any physical changes, deaths of friends, and losses of independence that could trigger depression.</li>
<li>You may also notice things like having trouble sleeping, or sleeping too much.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Finding_the_Cause_of_Depression_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Finding_the_Cause_of_Depression">Finding the Cause of Depression</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cope-with-a-Child%27s-Suicide-Step-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Cope-with-a-Child%27s-Suicide-Step-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cope with a Child's Suicide Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Cope-with-a-Child%27s-Suicide-Step-5.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Cope-with-a-Child%27s-Suicide-Step-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_7f6e5f12ea" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7f6e5f12ea')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cope with a Child's Suicide Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Cope-with-a-Child%27s-Suicide-Step-5.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Cope-with-a-Child%27s-Suicide-Step-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider potential causes and risk factors for depression.</b> Depression is a complex disorder, and there's no simple test doctors can do to see whether or not you have it. However, there are many tools a therapist may use to check for depression, including having you fill out a questionnaire. Certain experiences can also cause or put you at risk for depression and sharing this information with a doctor or therapist may help them to make a diagnosis. Some potential causes and risk factors for depression may include:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>
<b>Trauma and grief.</b> Abuse or other violent experiences can cause depression, whether they occurred recently or otherwise. Grief after the death of a friend or other traumatic event can develop into full blown depression.</li>
<li>
<b>Stressful events.</b> Sudden changes, even positive ones such as getting married or starting a new job, could be responsible. More long term stress from caring for a sick person or going through a messy divorce are common triggers as well.</li>
<li>
<b>Health conditions.</b> Chronic pain, thyroid disease, and many other medical conditions can bring on depression, especially if you are fighting a long battle with an illness.</li>
<li>
<b>Medication and substances.</b> Read the side effects label on any medication you are taking. Avoid alcohol and other drugs to see if your symptoms improve; depressed people often abuse drugs, which makes the problem worse.</li>
<li>
<b>Relationship problems</b>. If you are struggling in one or more of your personal relationships, then this may also put you at risk of depression.</li>
<li>
<b>Family history of depression</b>. If a relative of yours has struggled with depression, then you are at a higher risk of developing it yourself.</li>
<li>
<b>Loneliness, isolation, or a lack of social support</b>. If you do not have a support system and spend a lot of time on your own, then this can also put you at risk of depression.</li>
<li>
<b>Financial strain</b>. If you have been struggling with debt or simply trying to keep up with your monthly expenses, then this can put you at risk of depression.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-the-Baby-Whisperer%27s-Sleep-Method-Step-16.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Apply-the-Baby-Whisperer%27s-Sleep-Method-Step-16.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply the Baby Whisperer's Sleep Method Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Apply-the-Baby-Whisperer%27s-Sleep-Method-Step-16.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Apply-the-Baby-Whisperer%27s-Sleep-Method-Step-16.jpg" height="546" id="img_b194391d2e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b194391d2e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply the Baby Whisperer's Sleep Method Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Apply-the-Baby-Whisperer%27s-Sleep-Method-Step-16.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Apply-the-Baby-Whisperer%27s-Sleep-Method-Step-16.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider whether you may have postpartum depression.</b> If you recently gave birth, consider when the depression began. New mothers often experience mood swings, irritability, and other symptoms, which can range from minor to serious. If your depression began after delivery or at some point in the following few months, you may have postpartum depression.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Most new mothers experience "baby blues" symptoms for a few days, then recover on their own. This is probably due to hormonal changes and stress following birth.</li>
<li>If you are having suicidal thoughts, or the depression is preventing you from caring for your baby, or if the symptoms last more than a week or two, consult a doctor immediately.</li>
<li>Postpartum psychosis is a rare condition that can occur within two weeks of childbirth. If your depression symptoms are severe and accompanied by extreme mood swings, thoughts about harming your baby, or hallucinations, go to a hospital immediately.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-with-Periods-if-You-Are-Blind-or-Visually-Impaired-Step-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Deal-with-Periods-if-You-Are-Blind-or-Visually-Impaired-Step-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal with Periods if You Are Blind or Visually Impaired Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Deal-with-Periods-if-You-Are-Blind-or-Visually-Impaired-Step-3.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Deal-with-Periods-if-You-Are-Blind-or-Visually-Impaired-Step-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_1b2c001091" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1b2c001091')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal with Periods if You Are Blind or Visually Impaired Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Deal-with-Periods-if-You-Are-Blind-or-Visually-Impaired-Step-3.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Deal-with-Periods-if-You-Are-Blind-or-Visually-Impaired-Step-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider whether your depression may be linked to fall or winter.</b> If your symptoms appear as the days become shorter and darker, your depression may be Seasonal Affective Disorder, caused by too little sunlight. Exercise outdoors during daylight hours to see if you improve, or ask a doctor about artificial light treatment. <sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Not all temporary depression is seasonal affective disorder. Many people have depressive episodes that occur every few weeks, months, or years.</li>
<li>If you are especially manic and energetic when you are not depressed, tell a doctor you may have bipolar disorder.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Spot-Depression-Early-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Spot-Depression-Early-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Spot Depression Early Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Spot-Depression-Early-Step-9.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Spot-Depression-Early-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_3934256b32" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3934256b32')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Spot Depression Early Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Spot-Depression-Early-Step-9.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Spot-Depression-Early-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Don't dismiss your depression if none of these causes apply.</b> Many episodes of depression have a primarily biological or hormonal cause, or a cause that's difficult to identify. This does not make it any less serious or worth treating. Depression is a real medical condition, not something to feel ashamed of because you don't think you have a reason to be sad.

<ul>
<li>Tell yourself you will become better quicker if you take fast action to seek help.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Seeking_Treatment_for_Depression_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>4</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Seeking_Treatment_for_Depression">Seeking Treatment for Depression</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_4">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Prevent Teen Suicide Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-12.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_c8c873ce4b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c8c873ce4b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Prevent Teen Suicide Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-12.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Ask for help.</b> Reaching out to people can help you to take the first step towards treatment. Your feelings of helplessness are part of your disorder, not reality, and that isolation feeds those feelings. Friends and family can help by listening to your problems, encouraging you to do something about it, and supporting you during the worst moments.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you have trouble being active or leaving the house, let your friends know you're depressed and encourage them to keep inviting you to activities you enjoy even if you don't make it every time.</li>
<li>Asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-16.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-16.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Prevent Teen Suicide Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/32/Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-16.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-16.jpg" height="546" id="img_c2e4670cac" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c2e4670cac')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Prevent Teen Suicide Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/32/Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-16.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Prevent-Teen-Suicide-Step-16.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get a diagnosis.</b> It is important to see a doctor if you suspect that you may have depression. This is because there are other conditions that may mimic depression, and your doctor will need to rule those out first.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Keep in mind that it is okay to get a second or even a third opinion, especially if you do not think that the doctor is hearing you or is not concentrating on the area that you think is most important.

<ul>
<li>Your doctor can also give you a referral to see a therapist or a psychiatrist.</li>
<li>Your doctor won't necessarily prescribe medication. If she thinks there's a specific cause of your depression, she may recommend a course of action or lifestyle changes instead.</li>
<li>If your depression only lasts a few weeks and is gradually replaced by "high" periods of reckless energy, ask your doctor to consider bipolar disorder before taking any prescription medicine.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cope-with-a-Child%27s-Suicide-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Cope-with-a-Child%27s-Suicide-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cope with a Child's Suicide Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Cope-with-a-Child%27s-Suicide-Step-14.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Cope-with-a-Child%27s-Suicide-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_49b2cbc99e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_49b2cbc99e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cope with a Child's Suicide Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Cope-with-a-Child%27s-Suicide-Step-14.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Cope-with-a-Child%27s-Suicide-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Attend therapy or counseling.</b> There are many types of therapists or counselors that can help you through recovery. You may even consider group therapy or a support group. Ask your primary care doctor for a referral.

<ul>
<li>For example, you may find a depression support group to be helpful, or you may find a group like Alcoholics Anonymous or Narcotics Anonymous to be helpful if you have turned to substances as a way to cope.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be Patient when Trying Depression Treatments Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-9.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_5f5c6e57e4" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5f5c6e57e4')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be Patient when Trying Depression Treatments Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-9.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take antidepressant medication.</b> Once you are sure of your diagnosis and have begun taking steps to fight the depression, ask your doctor whether medication would be a good idea. Your doctor may prescribe antidepressants even if he thinks your main problem is an anxiety disorder, since they can be effective in treating those as well as depression.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Give the medication time to work. If you experience no changes after a few weeks, or if you can't stand the side effects, ask your doctor to prescribe a different medication.</li>
<li>Keep in mind that medication is not meant for long-term use. It can help with your symptoms, but you will likely need to seek other forms of treatment as well, such as therapy, to see significant improvement.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Seek-Help-for-Bipolar-Disorder-(Manic-Depression)-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Seek-Help-for-Bipolar-Disorder-(Manic-Depression)-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Seek Help for Bipolar Disorder (Manic Depression) Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Seek-Help-for-Bipolar-Disorder-%28Manic-Depression%29-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Seek-Help-for-Bipolar-Disorder-%28Manic-Depression%29-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_f761dd7980" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f761dd7980')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Seek Help for Bipolar Disorder (Manic Depression) Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Seek-Help-for-Bipolar-Disorder-%28Manic-Depression%29-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Seek-Help-for-Bipolar-Disorder-%28Manic-Depression%29-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Address the cause.</b> Removing the underlying cause can be an effective way of treating depression. However, it is best to do this with the help of a therapist.

<ul>
<li>If you are grieving, talk about your grief with friends, family, and mentors. Seek counseling to help you through the process. You can buy a workbook that addresses the grieving process as well.</li>
<li>If you recently underwent a big change, try to figure out what parts of the change made you unhappy. If you moved to a city where you don't know anyone, then get out and explore the area, find something to do that interests you, join a special interest group, or look for a new hobby that you can share with others. You may also consider volunteering because helping other people may help you to feel better about yourself. If you thought you would like the change and aren't sure why you're responding with depression, talk to a counselor.</li>
<li>If you suspect your depression is linked to your menstrual cycle or menopause, see a women’s health specialist, such as a gynecologist.</li>
<li>Consult a doctor, counselor, or specialized support group if you have a chronic illness or substance abuse problem.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cope-when-You%27ll-Never-See-Your-Crush-Again-(Girls)-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Cope-when-You%27ll-Never-See-Your-Crush-Again-(Girls)-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cope when You'll Never See Your Crush Again (Girls) Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Cope-when-You%27ll-Never-See-Your-Crush-Again-%28Girls%29-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Cope-when-You%27ll-Never-See-Your-Crush-Again-%28Girls%29-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_4a4ef33546" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4a4ef33546')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cope when You'll Never See Your Crush Again (Girls) Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Cope-when-You%27ll-Never-See-Your-Crush-Again-%28Girls%29-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Cope-when-You%27ll-Never-See-Your-Crush-Again-%28Girls%29-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Make-Friends" title="Make Friends">Cultivate good relationships</a>.</b> Keep your friends close and connect with them regularly. It is especially important to turn to your friends and family when you need someone to talk to. Simply sharing how you are feeling with someone may help you to feel better.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you want to make some new friends, then try joining a club of people who share an interest with you, or even a group you'd never thought of before. A regular meeting such as a weekly dance night or book club can make it easier to develop a habit of attending.</li>
<li>If you're too shy to speak to strangers at one of these events, a smile and eye contact can be enough to start a conversation. Find a smaller group or one with people you're more comfortable around if you're experiencing severe anxiety about it.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=132218" href="#/Image:Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be Patient when Trying Depression Treatments Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-11.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_2c0816cf12" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2c0816cf12')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be Patient when Trying Depression Treatments Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-11.jpg/aid132218-v4-728px-Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Be-Healthy" title="Be Healthy">Make healthy lifestyle changes</a>.</b> Regular and sufficient sleep, regular exercise, and a healthy diet are all vital to lowering stress and encouraging a healthy emotional state. Consider <a href="/Meditate" title="Meditate">meditation</a>, massage, or other relaxation techniques.

<ul>
<li>Use your support network. Ask about exercise advice from the professionals at your gym, and discuss relaxation methods including meditation. You can also research these topics online, or get a friend or housemate to help you build a schedule and stick to it.</li>
<li>Exercise is especially helpful to include in your routine because it causes your brain to release endorphins, which make you feel good.</li>
<li>Alcohol may temporarily relieve some of your depression, but it ultimately serves to worsen depression on a long-term basis. Drinking heavily may develop some symptoms of depression. Heavy drinking is known to lower the levels of serotonin in your brain, a chemical that helps boost your mood.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="298049" data-caid="298922" data-cqid="298066" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="341471" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105220" data-votes_down="13" data-votes_up="121">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">My mom thinks it is just stress and I will get over it, but I really do believe it is depression. Should I go to a guidance counselor?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=marshadurkin%2Crn#marshadurkin%2Crn" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/8/80/Marsha-Durkin.jpg/-crop-200-200-189px-Marsha-Durkin.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=marshadurkin%2Crn#marshadurkin%2Crn" target="_blank">Marsha Durkin, RN</a><br/>
	Registered Nurse
</div>
Marsha Durkin is a Registered Nurse in Wisconsin. She received her Associates Degree in Nursing from Olney Central College in 1987.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=marshadurkin%2Crn#marshadurkin%2Crn" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/8/80/Marsha-Durkin.jpg/-crop-200-200-189px-Marsha-Durkin.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=marshadurkin%2Crn#marshadurkin%2Crn" target="_blank">Marsha Durkin, RN</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Registered Nurse</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer"> Yes. You should definitely seek out your school social worker or guidance counselor.
</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>13</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>121</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="298050" data-caid="298923" data-cqid="298067" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="342119" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105220" data-votes_down="13" data-votes_up="100">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What if your friends won't listen and neither will your parents?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=marshadurkin%2Crn#marshadurkin%2Crn" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/8/80/Marsha-Durkin.jpg/-crop-200-200-189px-Marsha-Durkin.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=marshadurkin%2Crn#marshadurkin%2Crn" target="_blank">Marsha Durkin, RN</a><br/>
	Registered Nurse
</div>
Marsha Durkin is a Registered Nurse in Wisconsin. She received her Associates Degree in Nursing from Olney Central College in 1987.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=marshadurkin%2Crn#marshadurkin%2Crn" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/8/80/Marsha-Durkin.jpg/-crop-200-200-189px-Marsha-Durkin.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=marshadurkin%2Crn#marshadurkin%2Crn" target="_blank">Marsha Durkin, RN</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Registered Nurse</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Keep trying until you find someone who will listen to you, a teacher or social worker at school, or even your pastor if you attend church.
</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>13</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>100</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="119693" data-caid="120566" data-cqid="119710" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="895385" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="6" data-votes_up="99">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I never got diagnosed because I never asked, but I showed many symptoms and it lasted for nearly a year, but gradually got better on its own. Would this be considered depression?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">It could be. Depression can go away on its own, especially if you take good care of yourself and/or whatever may have triggered the depression (e.g., hormonal changes, negative life events or conditions) goes away.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>6</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>99</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="134986" data-caid="135859" data-cqid="135003" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="289366" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="22">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I'm totally isolated. How do I tell my parents that I need help if I do not have a strong bond with them or anyone?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Talking about it can be very difficult.  There are a number of anonymous online forums in which you can talk about it with others going through the same thing, such as 7 Cups of Tea (7cups.com).  </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>22</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="134991" data-caid="135864" data-cqid="135008" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="316710" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="22">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I've recently been dealing with depression. Although I had suffered from depression and fought it a few years ago, this time it feels different.  I feel that I'm trying my best, but reality hits me.  What should I do before it gets worse?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Talk with a therapist or counselor for the best path to take.  If you find going to a therapist too difficult, talk with a trusted friend or family member about how you're feeling.  Talk with your doctor about supplementing, boosting the dosage of, or changing your meds; sometimes their effectiveness tapers off over time.  Look at some alternative forms of therapy that you can do for yourself, such as meditation, mindfulness, aromatherapy, music and/or art therapy.  If you're not currently exercising three days per week, note that this has shown in numerous scientific studies to be as effective as antidepressants.  </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>22</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="164510" data-caid="165383" data-cqid="164527" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1084632" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="8" data-votes_up="114">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">If you smile or laugh, does it mean that you don't have depression?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">No, there is far more to clinical depression than whether or not you smile or laugh.  </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>8</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>114</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="88874" data-caid="89747" data-cqid="88891" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="714269" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="7" data-votes_up="99">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What if you don't feel comfortable talking to your parents about it because you know they will say your exaggerating and you have nothing to be depressed about? </div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Explain to them that depression is a disorder, not a choice. It has little to do with how good or bad a person's life objectively is, and it can happen to anyone. Things are just out of balance psychologically and/or chemically. You can give them some literature so they can learn more about it. In the meantime, please read and try to follow the guidelines in these articles: <a href="/Overcome-Depression" title="Overcome Depression">How to Overcome Depression</a>, <a href="/Protect-Your-Mind-With-Brain-Foods" title="Protect Your Mind With Brain Foods">How to Protect Your Mind With Brain Foods</a>.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>7</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>99</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="124262" data-caid="125135" data-cqid="124279" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="921485" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="8" data-votes_up="97">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What do you do if you are younger than a teenager and think you have depression? </div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Depression can happen at any age. Talk to your parents about it and ask if you could see a therapist. There are therapists for children. In the meantime, consider what in your life might have contributed to the depression. If there is something specific in your life that's depressing you, try to resolve the issue. If it feels out of nowhere, it could be the result of a chemical imbalance, which can sometimes be caused by chronic lack of sleep or poor diet. Make sure you take good care of yourself: sleep 9-11 hours a night on a consistent schedule, <a href="/Eat-Healthy" title="Eat Healthy">eat healthy</a>, and exercise regularly.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>8</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>97</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="134859" data-caid="135732" data-cqid="134876" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="985938" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="15" data-votes_up="149">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What if I'm young and I don't know how to get a therapist without anyone else knowing? (I don't want to tell anybody, but I want to be sure if I have depression.)</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You can find a lot of help online. There are many online forums available and there are sites where you can chat with people or look at symptom checklists. They probably won't be able to give you a concrete diagnosis though, and if you need help, you should not be afraid to ask for it.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>15</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>149</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="73614" data-caid="74487" data-cqid="73631" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="620119" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="12" data-votes_up="121">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What if I don't know why I might be depressed?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">That's perfectly normal. Sometimes there is no obvious cause, it might be a chemical imbalance in your brain - your brain may not be making enough seratonin. Depression can also be genetic. You should talk to a doctor about possible medication and/or therapy - there may be a root cause for your depression that you simply aren't aware of.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">

<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>121</span></a>

</div>
</li>
</ul>

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>Be prepared to improve in "baby steps". Don't expect to get better immediately after identifying your problem, but recognize small improvements and accomplishments along the way.</li>
<li>Depression is not a trivial thing. It is a real illness that needs to be treated. Just because depression isn't necessarily physical does not mean that it is something that can be overcome through sheer willpower. Seek help and treatment.</li>
<li>If you want it to be anonymous, call a hotline, but know that it is better to tell someone personally to get medical treatment or help.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>If you are depressed, some people may try to dismiss your symptoms. If they do not listen or seem to understand, seek out friends that do understand or you may also look into joining a support group that you can attend that deals with depression. Some people are just not able to deal with other people’s feelings.</li>
<li>If you suspect a friend is considering suicide, don't be afraid to talk to them about it directly.</li>
<li>If you're considering suicide or serious self-harm, call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup> Someone is available to help you 24 hours per day every day of the year. Remember that suicide is very serious, so do not hesitate to seek out help for yourself or for someone else.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="ur_review_text">
				"I have depression, untreated, undiagnosed, unnoticed. I do not know the cause of my depression. No one realizes it<span class="ur_review_more"> because I am of a young age, under fifteen.     "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",

    "headline": "Know if You Have Depression",
    "name": "Know if You Have Depression",
    "mainEntityOfPage": {
        "@type": "WebPage",
        "id": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/Know-if-You-Have-Depression"
    },

        "@type": "ImageObject",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/db\/Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-11.jpg\/aid132218-v4-1200px-Be-Patient-when-Trying-Depression-Treatments-Step-11.jpg",
        "width": 1200,
        "height": 900
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,

        },
        "sameAs": [
